ai-ud2.8:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kuṇḍiyā in the Kuṇḍadhāna Grove.
ai-ud2.8:1.3_0: Now at that time Suppavāsā the Koliyan had been pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days.
ai-ud2.8:1.4_0: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts help her endure:
ai-ud2.8:1.5_0: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:1.6_0: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:1.7_0: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”
ai-ud2.8:2.2_0: “Come, Master, you must go to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud2.8:2.2_1: and after approaching worship the Fortunate One’s feet in my name,
ai-ud2.8:2.3_0: and ask whether he is free from sickness, free from illness, in good health, and living comfortably, (and say):
ai-ud2.8:2.4_0: ‘The Koliyan lady Suppavāsā, reverend Sir, worships the Fortunate One’s feet with her head,
ai-ud2.8:2.5_0: and asks whether you are free from sickness, free from illness, in good health, and living comfortably.’
ai-ud2.8:2.7_0: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:2.8_0: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts help her endure:
ai-ud2.8:2.9_0: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:2.10_0: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:2.11_0: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”’”
ai-ud2.8:3.1_0: “(That is) the best thing”, said the Koliyan gentleman, and did as he was asked.
ai-ud2.8:3.2_0: While sat on one side the Koliyan gentleman said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud2.8:3.3_0: “Sir, the Koliyan lady Suppavāsā bows with her head to your feet. She asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
ai-ud2.8:3.5_0: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:3.6_0: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts help her endure:
ai-ud2.8:3.7_0: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:3.8_0: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.
ai-ud2.8:3.9_0: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”’”
ai-ud2.8:4.1_0: “May Suppavāsā the Koliyan be happy and healthy! May she give birth to a healthy child!”
ai-ud2.8:4.2_0: and may a healthy son give birth to a healthy son.”
ai-ud2.8:4.3_0: As soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.
ai-ud2.8:5.1_0: Saying “Yes, sir,” the Koliyan gentleman approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he returned to his own house.
ai-ud2.8:5.2_0: He saw that his wife, happy and healthy, had given birth to a healthy child,
ai-ud2.8:5.3_0: Having seen (that), this occurred to him:
ai-ud2.8:5.4_0: “It’s incredible, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might! For as soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.”
ai-ud2.8:5.5_0: He became uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.
ai-ud2.8:6.2_0: “Come, Master, you must go to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud2.8:6.2_1: and after approaching worship the Fortunate One’s feet in my name,
ai-ud2.8:6.3_0: ‘The Koliyan lady Suppavāsā, reverend Sir, worships the Fortunate One’s feet with her head.’
ai-ud2.8:6.5_0: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:6.6_0: Seven days (attracta) seven days, she is happy and healthy,
ai-ud2.8:6.7_0: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
ai-ud2.8:6.8_0: Sir, may the Buddha please accept seven meals from Suppavāsā.’”
ai-ud2.8:7.1_0: “(That is) the best thing”, said the Koliyan gentleman, and did as he was asked.
ai-ud2.8:7.2_0: While sat on one side the Koliyan gentleman said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud2.8:8.1_0: “The Koliyan lady Suppavāsā, reverend Sir, worships the Fortunate One’s feet with her head,
ai-ud2.8:8.3_0: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:8.4_0: Seven days (attracta) seven days, she is happy and healthy,
ai-ud2.8:8.5_0: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
ai-ud2.8:8.6_0: Sir, may the Buddha please accept seven meals from Suppavāsā.’”
ai-ud2.8:9.1_0: Now at that time a certain lay follower had already invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.
ai-ud2.8:9.2_0: That lay follower was Venerable Mahāmoggallāna’s supporter.
ai-ud2.8:9.3_0: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
ai-ud2.8:9.4_0: “Please, Moggallāna, go to the that lay follower and say to him,
ai-ud2.8:9.5_0: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:9.6_0: Seven days (attracta) seven days, she is happy and healthy,
ai-ud2.8:9.7_0: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
ai-ud2.8:9.8_0: Let the Koliyan lady Suppavāsā make her seven meals.’
ai-ud2.8:10.1_0: “Yes, sir,” Mahāmoggallāna replied. He went to that lay follower,
ai-ud2.8:10.1_1: and after going, he said this to that lay follower:
ai-ud2.8:10.2_0: “Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in difficult labor for seven days,
ai-ud2.8:10.3_0: Seven days (attracta) seven days, she is happy and healthy,
ai-ud2.8:10.4_0: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.
ai-ud2.8:10.5_0: Let Suppavāvā make seven meals, afterwards you can make mine.”
ai-ud2.8:11.1_0: “If, sir Venerable Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me three things—wealth, life, and faith—
ai-ud2.8:11.2_0: then let Suppavāvāvā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”
ai-ud2.8:11.3_0: “I can guarantee you two things—wealth and life.
ai-ud2.8:12.1_0: “If, sir Venerable Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me two things—wealth and life—
ai-ud2.8:12.2_0: then let Suppavāvāvā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”
ai-ud2.8:13.1_0: Having persuaded that lay follower, Mahāmoggallāna went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud2.8:13.1_1: and after going, he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud2.8:13.3_0: Let Suppavāvāvā make seven meals, afterwards he shall make his.”
ai-ud2.8:14.1_0: For seven days Suppavāsā served and satisfied the Buddha with her own hands with a variety of delicious foods. And she made her little boy bow to the Buddha and the mendicant Sangha.
ai-ud2.8:15.1_0: Then Sāriputta said to the boy,
ai-ud2.8:15.2_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, little boy? I hope you’re comfortable?”
ai-ud2.8:15.3_0: “How, reverend Sāriputta, can I bear up? How can I carry on?
ai-ud2.8:15.4_0: For seven years I lived in a pot of blood.”
ai-ud2.8:16.2_0: “My child is conversing with the General of the Dhamma!” was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.
ai-ud2.8:16.3_0: Knowing this, the Buddha said to her,
ai-ud2.8:16.4_0: “Would you like to have another child like this?”
ai-ud2.8:16.5_0: “Sir, I would like to have seven more children like this!”
ai-ud2.8:17.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud2.8:18.2_0: the disliked in the guise of the liked,
